title: Johnson Matthey raises prospect of investor payout

Wed, Jul 22, 2015, 14:40 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 50 mins Johnson Matthey raises prospect of investor payout By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 1 hour 36 minutes ago 2,896.00 -116.0000 
Johnson Matthey (LSE: JMAT.L - news ) , the world's largest maker of catalytic converters, plans to return cash from sale of businesses to shareholders 
Catalytic converter maker Johnson Matthey could return to investors the proceeds from almost £400m of disposals. 
The FTSE 100 group said in a trading update that unless it makes any material acquisitions it plans to return to shareholders “excess capital” from the sale of its research chemicals operation and from its gold and silver refining business. 
Johnson Matthey announced earlier this year that it had agreed to sell the research chemicals unit for £256m in cash and said on Wednesday that it expected the deal to complete by the end of the year. The gold and silver refining business was sold to Asahi Holdings for £124m and the transaction completed in March. 
The company gave no details of how large the return to shareholders would be, but Johnson Matthey is understood to believe it could make acquisitions totalling up to £300m and still be able to return money from the sales. 
It is the first time the company has formally mentioned the prospect of a shareholder return, and came as it reported group sales rose 6pc to £797m in the three months to the end of June. Underlying pre-tax profits dipped 1pc to £94m. 
Adjusting for the impact of the sale of the gold and silver refining business, revenue rose 8pc and profit was 1pc higher. 
The emission control technologies unit - the largest part of Johnson Matthey, which makes catalytic converters - posted a 6pc increase in revenue to £478m over the period. This was ahead of the global car production division, which was flat, and reflects tougher controls on vehicle exhaust emissions imposed by the EU. As a result, the unit sold more of its higher-value catalytic converters. 
Looking ahead, the company said that while it expected full-year results to be slightly ahead of the previous year, it did warn that sterling’s recent strengthening against the dollar and the drop in the price of precious metals could weigh. 
Johnson Matthey posted a pre-tax profit of £440m last year and the company said on Wednesday that foreign exchange rates and metal prices could cause a £10m headwind to its performance this year.
